digital-scriptorium.title: get iiif manifest uri's by MMS ID

comments.body:
Things I had to do to get this installing locally:

`HOMEBREW_NO_AUTO_UPDATE=1 brew upgrade postgresql`
Install Lando 3.18.0 from https://github.com/lando/lando/releases
`lando destroy`
`rake servers:start`

I ended up with a local postgres 14 which seemed to work but isn't exactly right. To get 15 I think we'd have to uninstall 14, install `postgresql@15`, and then follow the instructions in the prompt to add some path stuff to `~/.zshrc.local`

Background info that's relevant:

We can't make videos public that don't have captions. Videos that are not public (but accessible by the public) need to have a way to request captions and have that actually happen.

Questions that need answered:

- [ ] Is there a small thing we can do to close this ticket and iterate that bypasses that caption requirement? For instance - is it enough to ingest the video, make it playable, but not render it for non-staff.
- [ ] How does someone request captions?
- [ ] When requesting captions, what happens?
- [ ] How fast do captions need to turn around in?
- [ ] What kind of captions do we support?
- [ ] If a video gets uploaded without an associated caption file, what should Figgy do? Prevent marking complete? Prevent marking anything but private?
- [ ] For video that HAS no audio (silent films), what's best practice for captions? Do we still need a caption that says there's no audio or something, or is it just not an issue?

- [ ] We need a video WITH captions to test with.

Questions DLS needs to answer:

- [ ] Where are we going to put all these derivatives? The Isilon? That's where audio derivatives are, but the performance is slow and videos are a lot bigger. Do we need to store and stream these from the cloud?
- [ ] How do we model captions in Figgy? Presumably it's a separate file - how do we say that the video "1.mp4" is linked to the caption "1-caption.vtt", if there can be multiple videos in a single ScannedResource
Screenshot for reference:
I downloaded the errors from honeybadger and noticed that every time this has happened it's been a metadata node.
@tpendragon Did something happen on July 3rd -- any kind of batch re-preservation or re-check of some subset of resources?
https://github.com/pulibrary/figgy/issues/5556#issuecomment-1610390680 happened June 27, only thing I can think of.

I downloaded the honeybadger export and pulled out the preservation object ids and converted them to the resource ids. Here is the list of affected resources
```
> resources.map(&:id).map(&:to_s)                                                                                                                                         
=>                                            
["ddb13313-852d-440e-80cc-8ff13ec5bd65",

 "d6ecea8f-182e-4a4c-bfcc-0537ed802e45",

 "1dd680d3-dd3a-4796-bd20-046b458e2674",

 "b2d0ba66-53ad-44a0-ab46-a85435d47b23",
 "51dba73c-58da-4240-a498-0d8c41dd4a30",
 "ecfea54c-f4a6-4894-bbe5-2d462ff4d3a9",
 "8f3e3ac2-44a7-4a82-a591-4753776da324",
 "a448619d-e861-471b-9e28-e5b523143314",
 "68d6bb2b-7b90-484b-8e22-5b608c2522f1",
 "26dde925-7267-4aa8-bd90-9f908dd92765",
 "390b6a04-0910-4b21-a246-beb2f00f9516",
 "7ef2f8bf-c407-431f-907d-6bae36f77334",
 "8b7f6bff-6897-4d4a-9129-94e4cb995981",
 "9a6c0a83-158a-49a0-af93-366d153510a3",
 "b2f4db21-8299-4e6a-9a58-224f91330aa6",
 "5ef6bb28-dfb9-48bf-a250-f2af947c731c",
 "07b9429e-24ab-4217-8e56-82de929dae83",
 "a232d37e-f415-430d-9ea0-b33c89d50448",
 "ad7698df-657a-4981-876a-484008dcb1b2",
 "653779b1-7066-40b0-bd5d-91fb5d1b0984",
 "c65504eb-e918-42d3-ad80-f30a098a523e",
 "e6d24b64-11e4-4715-b495-8062d93a76a8",
 "61386913-ca81-4066-a6a1-3ee752ff6e22",
 "8f503630-351e-4325-ae1c-1fadc16f4e04",
 "f4f391f7-b470-436b-8b3b-61c00e632459",
 "879829ce-be93-4d65-a266-1237e69869c5",
 "4868d690-025e-4616-9fa8-c8f8ae064130",
 "ecbfd6ae-4096-4db3-b2b8-d7e81dfd5944",
 "7cb0b195-8edf-4f23-a926-e310bc299fbd",
 "757eac5b-92c7-4166-bf84-7902d846d985"]               
```

note that they are different kinds of resources: 
```
 resources.map(&:class)
=> 
[FileSet,
 ScannedMap,
 FileSet,
 FileSet,
 FileSet,
 FileSet,
 FileSet,
 FileSet,
 FileSet,
 ScannedResource,
 FileSet,
 FileSet,
 FileSet,
 FileSet,
 FileSet,
 Numismatics::Issue,
 FileSet,
 FileSet,
 ScannedResource,
 FileSet,
 FileSet,
 ScannedResource,
 ScannedResource,
 ScannedMap,
 Numismatics::Issue,
 FileSet,
 FileSet,
 ScannedMap,
 FileSet,
 FileSet,
 FileSet,
 FileSet,
 FileSet,
 ScannedMap,
 FileSet,
 FileSet,
 FileSet]
```

Looking at one of these, there is already more than one previous current event. When we do `.first` and update one of them to be `current: false`, there's still another one that's `current: true` https://github.com/pulibrary/figgy/blob/23fa2ad0c8b1329bb50cac3050e78023902552e3/app/jobs/cloud_fixity_job.rb#L65-L71

How did there come to be more than one current Event, considering we have the constraint? Maybe it doesn't matter, and we just have the code mark them all `current:false`, knowing we won't create more like this moving forward.

The constraint is:

No two events with metadata `'{"current": [true]}' and the same resource_id and child_id can exist.

You're saying there are cases in the DB where that happens?
Sorry I didn't realize this was for metadata - I think you're right, we should just mark them all `current: false`

princeton_ansible.title: Add headers to help troubleshooting error pages
attempt to pass HTML error codes through on the LB

comments.body:
Today we got this partially working. The necessary fixes/changes include:
1. add the `proxy_intercept_errors on;` directive in the `location` block of the site config (our test site config is `abid-staging`)
2. remove or comment out the inclusion of `/etc/nginx/conf.d/templates/staging-maintenance.conf` - this was active and working but uses the old syntax, and you can't have two `error_page` definitions 
3. include `/etc/nginx/conf.d/templates/errors.conf` - not sure if this should be in the `location` block or in the `server` block, right now it's in both
4. on the load balancer, copy `/var/local/www/default/index.html` (which is the deployed file created from the `roles/nginx/files/www/error.html` file) to `/var/local/www/default/error.html` (which is what the errors.conf file is looking for), with the correct permissions
5. add a specific error code you want to return, using `=XXX`, after the list of error codes to capture, in `errors.conf` (on the LB I set it to `=503`, in the git branch I've set it to `=500`)

With these changes, I consistently get the right results:
 - at the command line:
```
alicia@PULaptop ~ % curl -I https://abid-staging.princeton.edu
HTTP/2 503 
server: nginx/1.23.4
date: Mon, 31 Jul 2023 22:51:53 GMT
content-type: text/html
```
- in the browser:
![Screenshot 2023-07-31 at 6 05 52 PM](https://github.com/pulibrary/princeton_ansible/assets/879121/adbfa335-51b4-4911-a8a4-2b96a67f29ef)

Still not sure how to get the LB to pass "whatever the upstream error code is", but we're closer!
